Walker Percy

Leslie Marsh

Walker Percy's anti-rationalism issues forth from his concern with abstraction. Percy discerned what he took to be a distinctively twentieth-century (peculiarly Western) form of disquieted consciousness—a miasmic malaise—consisting in a loss of the self, brought about by fivefold inextricably linked phenomena: (a) first and foremost by our inherited bifurcated Cartesian self, and, derivatively, (b) an uncritical assimilation and extension of scientific a priorism, pejoratively known as scientism; (c) an atomistic social abstraction in the form of homo economicus, i.e. formalized rational maximizers; (d) the salvatory rationalism promised to consumers of ideas be it junk science, conspiracy theories, New Age movements, cults, gurus, fundamentalism, evangelicalism, zealotry of all kinds — that can be institutionalized as political, religious, or even academic charlatanism; and (e) a loss of a sense of place corroded by the ongoing creep of cultural homogeneity that has undermined the situated agent.
